title: Hydraulic Pump Component Maintenance Manual
content: This Component Maintenance Manual (CMM) provides detailed procedures for maintaining, repairing, and overhauling the Parker Hannifin PV3-300 hydraulic pump used on Boeing 737-800 aircraft. This manual includes disassembly, inspection, repair, assembly, and testing procedures for the hydraulic pump.

sections.title: Introduction
sections.content:
This Component Maintenance Manual (CMM) contains information necessary for the maintenance, repair, and overhaul of the Parker Hannifin PV3-300 hydraulic pump (P/N: HYD-PUMP-001) used on Boeing 737-800 aircraft. This manual is intended for use by properly trained and qualified maintenance personnel. All maintenance procedures must be performed in accordance with this manual and applicable regulatory requirements.

The PV3-300 is a variable displacement, pressure-compensated axial piston pump that provides hydraulic power to the aircraft's System A hydraulic system. The pump is driven by the aircraft engine accessory gearbox and delivers hydraulic fluid at a nominal pressure of 3,000 psi (20,684 kPa).

Cross-reference: For system-level information, refer to the Aircraft Maintenance Manual (doc-001).

sections.title: Safety Precautions
sections.content:
WARNING: Before performing any maintenance procedure, ensure that all necessary safety precautions are taken. Failure to observe safety precautions may result in personal injury, damage to equipment, or both.

CAUTION: The hydraulic pump contains parts that operate under high pressure. Ensure all pressure is relieved before disassembly.

The following safety precautions must be observed when working with the hydraulic pump:

1. Always wear appropriate personal protective equipment (PPE) including eye protection and chemical-resistant gloves
2. Ensure the work area is clean and free of contaminants
3. Use only approved tools and fixtures for disassembly and assembly
4. Properly dispose of used hydraulic fluid and components according to local regulations
5. Ensure all test equipment is properly calibrated before use
6. Follow all warnings and cautions in the specific maintenance procedures

sections.title: Pump Description and Operation
sections.content:
3.1 GENERAL DESCRIPTION

The Parker Hannifin PV3-300 hydraulic pump is a variable displacement, pressure-compensated axial piston pump. The pump consists of the following major components:

- Housing assembly
- Rotating group (cylinder block, pistons, and valve plate)
- Swashplate assembly
- Pressure compensator
- Drive shaft and bearings
- Case drain

3.2 PRINCIPLES OF OPERATION

The pump is driven by the aircraft engine accessory gearbox through a splined drive shaft. As the cylinder block rotates, the pistons reciprocate due to their contact with the angled swashplate. During the outward stroke, hydraulic fluid is drawn into the cylinder bores through the valve plate. During the inward stroke, the fluid is pressurized and discharged through the valve plate to the pressure port.

The pressure compensator automatically adjusts the swashplate angle to maintain the desired output pressure (3,000 psi / 20,684 kPa). When system pressure reaches the compensator setting, the swashplate angle is reduced, decreasing the pump's displacement and flow rate. This variable displacement feature allows the pump to deliver only the flow required by the system, reducing power consumption and heat generation.

3.3 SPECIFICATIONS

- Maximum Operating Pressure: 3,500 psi (24,132 kPa)
- Nominal Operating Pressure: 3,000 psi (20,684 kPa)
- Maximum Flow Rate: 30 gallons per minute (114 liters per minute)
- Operating Temperature Range: -40°F to +275°F (-40°C to +135°C)
- Weight: 18.5 pounds (8.4 kg)
- Mounting: SAE 4-bolt flange
- Drive Shaft: Splined per SAE J744 standard

Cross-reference: For detailed parts information, refer to the Illustrated Parts Catalog (doc-003).

sections.title: Maintenance Procedures
sections.content:
4.1 REMOVAL AND INSTALLATION

WARNING: Ensure all hydraulic pressure is relieved before removing the pump. Failure to do so may result in personal injury or equipment damage.

Tools Required:
- Standard mechanic's tool set
- Torque wrench (0-50 ft-lb / 0-68 Nm)
- Hydraulic fitting caps

Removal Procedure:
1. Ensure the aircraft hydraulic system is depressurized and the engine is shut down
2. Disconnect the electrical connector from the pressure switch
3. Place a container under the pump to catch any residual hydraulic fluid
4. Disconnect and cap the pressure and suction lines
5. Remove the four mounting bolts securing the pump to the accessory gearbox
6. Carefully remove the pump from the engine
7. Cap all openings to prevent contamination

Installation Procedure:
1. Ensure the mounting surface on the accessory gearbox is clean and free of debris
2. Verify the drive splines are undamaged and properly lubricated
3. Align the pump drive splines with the gearbox drive and carefully install the pump
4. Install the four mounting bolts and torque to 35-40 ft-lb (47-54 Nm)
5. Remove the protective caps and connect the pressure and suction lines
6. Torque the hydraulic fittings according to the aircraft maintenance manual
7. Connect the electrical connector to the pressure switch
8. Perform a leak check and functional test as described in Section 4.4

4.2 DISASSEMBLY

CAUTION: Disassembly should only be performed by properly trained personnel in a clean environment.

Tools Required:
- Special disassembly fixture (P/N: HYD-TOOL-101)
- Bearing puller set
- Snap ring pliers
- Soft-faced hammer

Procedure:
1. Drain all hydraulic fluid from the pump
2. Mount the pump in the disassembly fixture
3. Remove the pressure compensator assembly
4. Remove the end cap retaining bolts and carefully remove the end cap
5. Remove the valve plate
6. Carefully extract the cylinder block, pistons, and swashplate assembly
7. Remove the drive shaft retaining ring and press the shaft out of the housing
8. Remove and discard all O-rings and seals

Refer to the detailed disassembly instructions in the Overhaul Manual for specific component removal procedures.

4.3 INSPECTION AND REPAIR

All components must be thoroughly cleaned and inspected before reassembly. The following inspection criteria apply:

Housing:
- Check for cracks, corrosion, or damage
- Inspect bearing bores for wear or damage
- Maximum allowable bore diameter: 2.8465 inches (72.301 mm)

Drive Shaft:
- Check for wear, cracks, or damage to splines
- Inspect bearing journals for scoring or wear
- Minimum allowable journal diameter: 1.1815 inches (30.010 mm)

Cylinder Block:
- Check for scoring, wear, or damage to cylinder bores
- Inspect valve plate contact surface for flatness
- Maximum allowable bore diameter: 0.5512 inches (14.000 mm)

Pistons:
- Check for scoring, wear, or damage
- Minimum allowable diameter: 0.5500 inches (13.970 mm)

Swashplate:
- Check for scoring, wear, or damage to piston contact surface
- Inspect bearings for smooth operation

Pressure Compensator:
- Check spring for damage or loss of tension
- Inspect spool for free movement and wear

Replace any components that do not meet the inspection criteria.

4.4 TESTING

After installation or overhaul, the pump must be tested to verify proper operation:

Leak Test:
1. Operate the hydraulic system at normal pressure (3,000 psi / 20,684 kPa)
2. Check for external leaks at all fittings and the pump housing
3. Monitor the case drain flow (maximum allowable: 1.5 gallons per minute / 5.7 liters per minute)

Performance Test:
1. Measure pump output flow at various pressure settings
2. Verify pressure compensation function
3. Check for unusual noise or vibration

Acceptance Criteria:
- No external leaks
- Case drain flow within limits
- Output flow within 10% of specified value
- Smooth pressure compensation
- No unusual noise or vibration

Record all test results in the aircraft maintenance log.

sections.title: Troubleshooting
sections.content:
5.1 TROUBLESHOOTING GUIDE

This section provides guidance for identifying and resolving common hydraulic pump issues.

Symptom: Low or No Pump Output
Possible Causes:
1. Worn or damaged pistons or cylinder block
   - Disassemble pump and inspect components
   - Replace worn or damaged parts
2. Damaged valve plate
   - Inspect valve plate for scoring or damage
   - Replace if necessary
3. Incorrect swashplate angle
   - Check pressure compensator adjustment
   - Repair or replace pressure compensator
4. Air in the hydraulic system
   - Bleed air from the system
   - Check for suction leaks

Symptom: Excessive Noise or Vibration
Possible Causes:
1. Cavitation
   - Check for restricted suction line
   - Verify proper fluid level in reservoir
2. Worn bearings
   - Disassemble pump and inspect bearings
   - Replace if necessary
3. Misalignment
   - Check mounting and alignment
   - Correct as necessary
4. Damaged pistons or cylinder block
   - Disassemble and inspect components
   - Replace damaged parts

Symptom: Excessive Case Drain Flow
Possible Causes:
1. Worn pistons or cylinder bores
   - Disassemble and inspect components
   - Replace worn parts
2. Damaged valve plate
   - Inspect valve plate for scoring or damage
   - Replace if necessary
3. Worn shaft seal
   - Replace shaft seal

Symptom: Failure to Maintain Pressure
Possible Causes:
1. Pressure compensator malfunction
   - Check compensator adjustment
   - Repair or replace compensator
2. Internal leakage
   - Disassemble and inspect components
   - Replace worn or damaged parts
3. External leakage
   - Check for leaks at fittings and seals
   - Tighten fittings or replace seals

CAUTION: Always refer to the appropriate Service Bulletin (SB-2025-01, doc-004) for the latest troubleshooting information and updates to maintenance procedures.

sections.title: Storage and Handling
sections.content:
6.1 STORAGE REQUIREMENTS

When storing the hydraulic pump, the following requirements must be met:

1. Clean the pump thoroughly before storage
2. Drain all hydraulic fluid and fill with storage preservative oil (P/N: PRES-OIL-001)
3. Cap all openings to prevent contamination
4. Store in a clean, dry environment with temperature between 40°F and 120°F (4°C and 49°C)
5. Avoid exposure to direct sunlight or sources of ozone
6. Rotate the shaft by hand one full revolution every 30 days during storage
7. Maximum storage period: 2 years

6.2 HANDLING PRECAUTIONS

When handling the hydraulic pump, observe the following precautions:

1. Always use proper lifting techniques and equipment
2. Avoid impact or dropping which may damage internal components
3. Keep all ports capped until ready for installation
4. Protect the drive splines from damage
5. Maintain cleanliness to prevent contamination

6.3 SHIPPING REQUIREMENTS

When shipping the hydraulic pump, the following requirements must be met:

1. Drain all hydraulic fluid and fill with shipping preservative
2. Cap all openings to prevent contamination
3. Package in a suitable container with adequate cushioning
4. Mark the package with appropriate handling instructions
5. Include a copy of the maintenance records if shipping for repair or overhaul

NOTE: For long-term storage or shipping, refer to Service Bulletin SB-2025-01 (doc-004) for additional requirements.
